</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;29, 2000 (fiscal 1999), the Board of Directors authorized a
common stock repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250.0 million of the Company&#146;s common shares. The Company completed this $250.0 million repurchase program during the first quarter of fiscal 2005. On March&nbsp;24, 2005, the
Company&#146;s Board of Directors authorized an additional share repurchase program of up to $200.0 million of the Company&#146;s common shares. The Company completed this $200.0 million repurchase program during the third quarter of fiscal 2005. On
September&nbsp;15, 2005, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors authorized a new share repurchase program of up to $200.0 million of the Company&#146;s common shares. Share repurchases under this program may be made through open market and privately
negotiated transactions from time to time and in such amounts as management deems appropriate. As of January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company has repurchased 7,682,700 shares at a cost of approximately $282.7 million under these programs in fiscal 2005,
bringing the combined total of repurchases under these programs to 16,690,400 shares at a cost of approximately $479.0 million. The maximum dollar value of common shares that may yet be purchased under the current program is approximately $171.0
million as of January 28, 2006. During the first quarter of fiscal 2006 (through March 31, 2006), the Company repurchased 1,602,000 shares at a cost of $68.2 million. All repurchased shares are held in treasury. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">20 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_10"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;6.</U> <U>SELECTED FINANCIAL DATA</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The information included in the Company&#146;s Annual
Report to Shareholders for the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;28, 2006 (the Annual Report) under the section entitled &#147;Selected Financial Data&#148; is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_11"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;7.</U> <U>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The information included in the Annual Report under the section entitled &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_12"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;7A.</U> <U>QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company limits its
interest rate risks by investing certain of its excess cash balances in short-term, highly-liquid instruments with an original maturity of one year or less. The Company does not expect any material losses from its invested cash balances and the
Company believes that its interest rate exposure is modest. As of January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company&#146;s cash and cash equivalents totaled approximately $372,586,000. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Additionally, the Company may from time to time borrow money under its revolving credit facility at various interest-rate options based on the prime rate or the Eurodollar rate depending upon certain financial tests.
Accordingly, the Company may be exposed to interest rate risk on money that it borrows under its credit facility. The Company did not have any amounts outstanding under the facility at January&nbsp;28, 2006 and January&nbsp;29, 2005. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company does not have any material foreign currency exposure as nearly all of its business is transacted in United States currency. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_13"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;8.</U> <U>FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The information included in the Annual
Report under the sections entitled: &#147;Consolidated Statements of Operations,&#148; &#147;Consolidated Balance Sheets,&#148; &#147;Consolidated Statements of Changes in Shareholders&#146; Equity,&#148; &#147;Consolidated Statements of Cash
Flows&#148; and &#147;Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#148; are incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_14"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;9.</U> <U>CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">None. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">21 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx65535_15"></A><U>ITEM&nbsp;9A.</U> <U>CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</U> </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(a) Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The management of the Company established and maintains disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that material information relating to the Company
and its subsidiaries required to be disclosed in the reports that are filed or submitted under the 1934 Act are recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms, and that such
information is accumulated and communicated to management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. The Company carried out an evaluation, under the
supervision and with the participation of management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of disclosure controls and procedures as of the end of the period covered by
this report. Based on that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of the date of such evaluation. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(b) Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting. As defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f), internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the
supervision of, the principal executive and principal financial officer and effected by the board of directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and includes those policies and procedures that: (i)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that in reasonable detail accurately and fairly
reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting
principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of
unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under the
supervision and with the participation of management, including the&nbsp;Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, the Company carried out an evaluation of the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting as of
January&nbsp;28, 2006 based on the &#147;Internal Control - Integrated Framework&#148; issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO). Based upon this evaluation, management concluded that the Company&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January&nbsp;28, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">BDO Seidman, LLP, the independent registered certified public
accounting firm that audited the Company&#146;s financial statements included in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, has also audited management&#146;s assessment of the effectiveness of&nbsp;the Company&#146;s&nbsp;internal control over financial
reporting and the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as of January&nbsp;28, 2006 as stated in their report incorporated herein as part of the Company&#146;s Annual Report. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">22 </FONT></P>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-13.1
<SEQUENCE>2
<FILENAME>dex131.htm
<DESCRIPTION>THE SECTIONS OF THE COMPANY'S ANNUAL REPORT
<TEXT>
<HTML><HEAD>
<TITLE>The sections of the Company's Annual Report</TITLE>
</HEAD>
 <BODY BGCOLOR="WHITE">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Exhibit 13.1 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>SELECTED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL DATA </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The selected consolidated financial data of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble, Inc. and its
subsidiaries (collectively, the Company) set forth on the following pages should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and notes included elsewhere in this report. The Company&#146;s fiscal year is comprised of 52 or 53
weeks, ending on the Saturday closest to the last day of January. The Statement of Operations Data for the 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;28, 2006 (fiscal 2005), 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;29, 2005 (fiscal 2004) and 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;31,
2004 (fiscal 2003) and the Balance Sheet Data as of January&nbsp;28, 2006 and January&nbsp;29, 2005 are derived from, and are qualified by reference to, audited consolidated financial statements which are included elsewhere in this report. The
Statement of Operations Data for the 52 weeks ended February&nbsp;1, 2003 (fiscal 2002) and 52 weeks ended February&nbsp;2, 2002 (fiscal 2001) and the Balance Sheet Data as of January&nbsp;31, 2004,&nbsp;February&nbsp;1, 2003 and February&nbsp;2,
2002 are derived from audited consolidated financial statements not included in this report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="60%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fiscal 2002, the Company determined that a decrease in value in certain of its equity investments occurred which was other than temporary. As a result, other expense of $16,498
in fiscal 2002 includes the recognition of losses of $11,485 in excess of what would otherwise have been recognized by application of the equity method in accordance with Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;18, &#147;The Equity Method of
Accounting for Investments in Common Stock&#148;. The $16,498 loss in other expense was primarily comprised of $8,489 attributable to iUniverse.com, $5,081 attributable to <I>BOOK<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>&reg;<FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"></FONT></SUP><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"></FONT></FONT></I> magazine and $2,351 attributable to enews, inc. Included in other expense in fiscal 2001 is a loss of $12,066 from

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Comparable store sales increase (decrease) is calculated on a 52-week basis, and includes sales of stores that have been open for 15 months. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-1 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble, Inc.&#146;s (Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble or the Company) fiscal year is comprised of 52 or 53 weeks, ending on the Saturday closest
to the last day of January. As used in this section, &#147;fiscal 2006&#148; represents the 53 weeks ending February&nbsp;3, 2007, &#147;fiscal 2005&#148; represents the 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;28, 2006, &#147;fiscal 2004&#148; represents the 52
weeks ended January&nbsp;29, 2005 and &#147;fiscal 2003&#148; represents the 52 weeks ended January&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>General </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company is the nation&#146;s largest bookseller</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>1</SUP></FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000">, and as of January&nbsp;28, 2006 operated 799 bookstores and a Web site. Of the 799 bookstores, 681 operate primarily under the Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble Booksellers trade name (27 of which were opened
in fiscal 2005) and 118 operate primarily under the B. Dalton Bookseller trade name. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble conducts the online part of its business through barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com), one of the largest sellers of books
on the Internet. Through Sterling Publishing Co., Inc. (Sterling), the Company is a leading general trade book publisher. Additionally, the Company owns an approximate 74% interest in Calendar Club L.L.C. (Calendar Club), an operator of seasonal
kiosks. The Company employed approximately 39,000 full- and part-time employees as of January&nbsp;28, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble
stores are located in all 50 states and the District of Columbia as of January&nbsp;28, 2006. With 40 years of bookselling experience, management has a strong sense of customers&#146; changing needs and the Company leads book retailing with a
&#147;community store&#148; concept. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble&#146;s typical store offers a comprehensive title base, a caf&eacute;, a children&#146;s section, a music department, a magazine section and a calendar of ongoing events, including author
appearances and children&#146;s activities, that make each Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store an active part of its community. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores range in size from 10,000 to 60,000 square feet depending upon market size with an overall average store size of 25,000 square feet. Each store features an authoritative selection of books, ranging from 60,000
to 200,000 unique titles. The comprehensive title selection is diverse and tailored to each store location to reflect local interests. In addition, Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble emphasizes books published by small and independent publishers and university
presses. Bestsellers (the &#147;top ten&#148; highest selling hardcover fiction, hardcover non-fiction and trade paperback titles) typically represent between 3% and 5% of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store sales. Complementing this extensive in-store
selection, all Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores provide customers with on-site access to the millions of books available to online shoppers while offering an option to have the book sent to the store or shipped directly to the customer through
Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s delivery system. All Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores are equipped with its proprietary BookMaster in-store operating system, which enhances the Company&#146;s merchandise-replenishment system, resulting in high
in-stock positions and productivity at the store level through efficiencies in receiving, cashiering and returns processing. The Company has integrated the BookMaster system used in its stores with Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com so that its customers
share the same experience across both channels. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During fiscal 2005, the Company added 0.5&nbsp;million square feet to the
Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store base, bringing the total square footage to 16.9&nbsp;million square feet, a 3% increase over the prior year. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores contributed approximately 85% of the Company&#146;s total sales in fiscal 2005.
The Company plans to open between 30 and 40 Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores in fiscal 2006, which are expected to average 28,000 square feet in size. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><HR WIDTH="8%"
SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" ALIGN="left">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>1</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000">Based upon sales reported in trade publications and public filings. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-2 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the end of fiscal 2005, the Company operated 118 B. Dalton bookstores in 37 states and the District of
Columbia. B. Dalton bookstores employ merchandising strategies that target the mainstream consumer book market, offering a wide range of bestsellers and general-interest titles. Most B. Dalton bookstores range in size from 2,000 to 6,000 square
feet, and while they are appropriate to the size of adjacent mall tenants, the opening of book superstores in nearby locations continues to have a significant adverse impact on B. Dalton bookstores. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company is continuing its controlled descent in the number of its smaller format B. Dalton bookstores in response to declining sales attributable
primarily to book superstore competition. Part of the Company&#146;s strategy has been to close underperforming stores, which has resulted in the closing of 849 B. Dalton bookstores since 1989. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of all of Bertelsmann AG&#146;s (Bertelsmann) interest in barnesandnoble.com inc.
(bn.com) and Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com. As a result of the acquisition, the Company increased its economic interest in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com from approximately 38% to approximately 75%. On May&nbsp;27, 2004, the Company completed a merger
(the Merger) of bn.com with a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company. The Merger was approved by the shareholders of bn.com at a special meeting held on May&nbsp;27, 2004. As a result of the Merger, bn.com became a privately held company, wholly
owned by the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com sells books, music and movies, and, to a lesser extent, used books, gifts, educational
games, toys and video games. With access to one of the industry&#146;s largest in-stock inventories of new books, Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com can offer fast delivery throughout the U.S. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s unique service,
&#147;Fast&amp;Free Delivery,&#148; enables customers in the continental U.S. to receive their deliveries within three business days, with no delivery charge on purchases of $25 and over. Visited by millions of users each month, Barnes&nbsp;&amp;
Noble.com has shipped products to customers in 230 countries since its inception in 1997. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com provides exclusive content features such as &#147;Meet the Writers,&#148; &#147;What America&#146;s Reading,&#148; audio and video
author interviews, and online reading groups, as well as third-party reviews, first chapters and table of contents, and thousands of music clips and video trailers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the fourth quarter 2005 American Customer Satisfaction Index compiled by the University of Michigan, Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com received the highest rating in the e-commerce category for the second year in a row.
This annual survey is recognized as the industry&#146;s leading indicator of customer satisfaction. According to the comScore MediaMetrix December 2005 report, Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s site was the twenty-first most-trafficked shopping
destination, as measured by the number of unique visitors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s subsidiary Sterling is a leading general trade book
publisher. Sterling&#146;s active title list comprises over 5,000 titles, and it publishes several hundred new titles each year. Sterling&#146;s publication list is particularly extensive in &#147;books for enthusiasts,&#148; categories that
include, mind enhancement, puzzles and games, crafts, home repair and remodeling, woodworking, photography, and wines and spirits. Sterling&#146;s list comprises books that it originates itself, purchases from domestic and international book
packagers and those that it distributes for other publishers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fiscal 2004, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors approved an overall
plan for the complete disposition of all of its Class&nbsp;B common stock in GameStop Corp. (GameStop), the Company&#146;s former video </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-3 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">game operating segment. This disposition was completed in two steps. The first step was the sale of 6,107,338 shares of
GameStop Class&nbsp;B common stock held by the Company to GameStop (Stock Sale) for an aggregate consideration of $111.5 million. The Stock Sale was completed on October&nbsp;1, 2004. The second step in the disposition was the spin-off by the
Company of its remaining 29,901,662 shares of GameStop&#146;s Class B common stock (Spin-Off). The Spin-Off was completed on November&nbsp;12, 2004 with the distribution of 0.424876232 of a share of GameStop Class&nbsp;B common stock as a tax-free
distribution on each outstanding share of the Company&#146;s common stock to the Company&#146;s stockholders of record as of the close of business on November&nbsp;2, 2004. As a result of the Stock Sale and the Spin-Off, GameStop is no longer a
subsidiary of the Company. The disposition of all of the Company&#146;s stockholdings in GameStop resulted in the Company presenting all historical results of operations of GameStop as discontinued operations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Results of Operations </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-5 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>52 Weeks Ended January&nbsp;28, 2006 Compared with 52 Weeks Ended January&nbsp;29, 2005 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Sales </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s sales increased $229.4
million, or 4.7%, during fiscal 2005 to $5.103 billion from $4.874 billion during fiscal 2004. This increase was attributable to a $235.2 million increase in sales at Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores and a $19.8 million increase in sales at
Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com, offset by a $34.9 million decrease in sales at B. Dalton stores. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store sales
increased $235.2 million, or 5.7%, during fiscal 2005 to $4.357 billion from $4.121 billion during fiscal 2004 and accounted for 85.4% of total Company sales. The 5.7% increase in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store sales was attributable to an increase
in comparable store sales of 2.9%, coupled with the opening of 27 new stores during fiscal 2005, which contributed to a 3.0% increase in square footage. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fiscal 2005, B. Dalton sales declined 19.8% and represented 2.8% of total Company sales. The decrease was primarily a result of 36 store closings and a 27.7% reduction in square footage, offset by an increase in
comparable store sales of 0.9% in fiscal 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fiscal 2005, the Company opened 27 Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores and closed 12,
bringing its total number of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores to 681 with 16.9&nbsp;million square feet. The Company closed 36 B. Dalton stores, ending the period with 118 B. Dalton stores and 0.5&nbsp;million square feet. As of January&nbsp;28, 2006,
the Company operated 799 stores in the fifty states and the District of Columbia. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cost of Sales and Occupancy </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s cost of sales and occupancy includes costs such as merchandise costs, distribution center costs (including payroll, supplies,
depreciation, and other operating expenses), rental expense, common area maintenance, merchant association dues and lease-required advertising, partially offset by landlord tenant allowances, amortized over the life of the lease. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cost of sales and occupancy increased $146.4 million, or 4.3%, to $3.533 billion in fiscal 2005 from $3.387 billion in fiscal 2004. As a percentage of
sales, cost of sales and occupancy decreased to 69.2% in fiscal 2005 from 69.5% in fiscal 2004. This decrease was due to less purchases from book wholesalers at higher costs than direct purchases from publishers, higher purchases through the
Company&#146;s distribution network, reduced sales of lower margin music and increased sales volume leveraging fixed occupancy costs in the Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores, offset by the deep discounted selling price on J. K. Rowling&#146;s <I>Harry
Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</I> book. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Selling and Administrative Expenses </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling and administrative expenses increased $81.9 million, or 7.8%, to $1.134 billion in fiscal 2005 from $1.052 billion in fiscal 2004. As a percentage
of sales, selling and administrative expenses increased to 22.2% in fiscal 2005 from 21.6% in fiscal 2004. This increase was primarily due to a $12.7 million charge related to the impairment of certain store assets, charges associated with
litigation of approximately $6.9 million and $3.6 million related to stock compensation costs associated with the issuance of restricted stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-6 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Depreciation and Amortization </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Depreciation and amortization decreased $8.6 million, or 4.7%, to $173.0 million in fiscal 2005 from $181.6 million in fiscal 2004. This decrease was primarily due to lower amortization of the Barnes&nbsp;&amp;
Noble.com customer lists and relationships, and certain Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store assets becoming fully depreciated. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Pre-Opening Expenses
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pre-opening expenses increased $2.1 million, or 23.4%, in fiscal 2005 to $10.9 million from $8.9 million in fiscal 2004. The increase
in pre-opening expenses was primarily due to the timing of new Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores opened during fiscal 2005 and those to be opened during the beginning of fiscal 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Operating Profit </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s consolidated operating profit increased $7.6 million, or 3.1%,
to $251.8 million in fiscal 2005 from $244.2 million in fiscal 2004. This increase was primarily due to the matters discussed above. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Interest Expense,
Net and Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Interest expense, net of interest income, and amortization of deferred financing fees,
decreased $9.6 million, or 87.2%, to $1.4 million in fiscal 2005 from $11.0 million in fiscal 2004. The decrease was primarily due to reduced average borrowings, the repayment of the Company&#146;s prior outstanding $245 million term loan and
interest income increasing $3.5 million, or 100.0%, to $7.0 million in fiscal 2005 from $3.5 million in fiscal 2004. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Debt Redemption Charge
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company completed the redemption of its $300.0 million outstanding 5.25% convertible subordinated notes due 2009 in the second
quarter of fiscal 2004. The write-off of the unamortized portion of the deferred financing fees from the issuance of the notes and the redemption premium resulted in a charge of $14.6 million. The debt redemption charge of $14.6 million in fiscal
2004 was comprised of an $8.5 million redemption premium and the write-off of $6.1 million of unamortized deferred financing fees from the issuance of the notes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Income Taxes </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble&#146;s effective tax rate in fiscal 2005 decreased to 40.75% compared with 43.00%
during fiscal 2004. The decrease in the effective tax rate was primarily due to adjustments in fiscal 2004 related to prior year taxes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Minority
Interest </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Minority interest was $1.7 million in fiscal 2005 compared with $1.2 million in fiscal 2004, and relates to the approximate
26% outside interest in Calendar Club L.L.C. (Calendar Club). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-7 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Income From Discontinued Operations </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;1, 2004, the Board of Directors of the Company approved an overall plan for the complete disposition of all of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common stock in GameStop Corp., the Company&#146;s former
video game operating segment. The plan was completed in November 2004 with the distribution to the Company&#146;s stockholders of the GameStop Class B common stock. As a result, GameStop is no longer a subsidiary of the Company and, accordingly, the
Company is presenting all historical results of operations of GameStop as discontinued operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Earnings </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a result of the factors discussed above, the Company reported consolidated net earnings of $146.7 million (or $2.03 per share) during fiscal 2005
compared with net earnings of $143.4 million (or $1.93 per share) during fiscal 2004. Components of diluted earnings per share (EPS) are as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="86%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-right:0px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Fiscal year</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2005</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2004</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">EPS from continuing operations</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">2.03</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">1.68</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">EPS from discontinued operations</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#151;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0.25</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Consolidated EPS</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">2.03</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">1.93</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>52 Weeks Ended January&nbsp;29, 2005 Compared with 52 Weeks Ended January&nbsp;31, 2004 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Sales </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s sales increased $501.4
million, or 11.5%, during fiscal 2004 to $4.874 billion from $4.372 billion during fiscal 2003. The increase in sales was primarily attributable to a $261.1 million increase in sales at Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores and the increase of $268.6
million in sales at Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store sales increased $261.1 million, or 6.8%, during fiscal 2004 to $4.121 billion from $3.860 billion during fiscal 2003 and accounted for 84.6% of total Company sales. The
6.8% increase in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble store sales was attributable to an increase in comparable store sales of 3.1% coupled with the opening of 32 new stores during fiscal 2004, which contributed to a 3.7% increase in square footage. This
increase was partially offset by declining sales of B. Dalton, due to 41 store closings and a comparable store sales decline of (2.2)% in fiscal 2004. Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com sales increased $268.6 million primarily due to the full year
consolidation of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com in fiscal 2004 compared with a partial year in fiscal 2003 resulting from the Company&#146;s acquisition of a controlling interest in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com on September&nbsp;15, 2003. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cost of Sales and Occupancy </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s cost
of sales and occupancy includes costs such as merchandise costs, distribution center costs (including payroll, supplies, depreciation and other operating expenses), rental expense, common area maintenance, merchant association dues and
lease-required advertising, partially offset by landlord tenant allowances amortized over the life of the lease. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cost of sales and
occupancy increased $326.2 million, or 10.7%, to $3.387 billion in fiscal 2004 from $3.060 billion in fiscal 2003, primarily due to the inclusion of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s cost of sales </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-8 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">and occupancy for the full period in fiscal 2004 compared with a partial period in fiscal 2003. As a percentage of sales,
cost of sales and occupancy decreased to 69.5% in fiscal 2004 from 70.0% in fiscal 2003. This decrease was primarily attributable to the reduction in bestseller markdowns and leverage on fixed occupancy costs. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Selling and Administrative Expenses </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling and
administrative expenses increased $141.9 million, or 15.6%, to $1,052.3 million in fiscal 2004 from $910.4 million in fiscal 2003, partially due to the inclusion of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s selling and administrative expenses for the full
period in fiscal 2004 compared with a partial period in fiscal 2003. As a percentage of sales, selling and administrative expenses increased to 21.6% in fiscal 2004 from 20.8% in fiscal 2003. This increase was partially due to the inclusion of
Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s selling and administrative expenses for the full period in fiscal 2004 compared with a partial period in fiscal 2003. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Depreciation and Amortization </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Depreciation and amortization increased $14.7 million, or 8.8%, to $181.6 million in fiscal
2004 from $166.8 million in fiscal 2003. This increase was due to the inclusion of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com&#146;s depreciation and amortization for the full period in fiscal 2004 compared with a partial period in fiscal 2003, offset by a
reduction in depreciation and amortization in the Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Pre-Opening Expenses </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pre-opening expenses increased $0.2 million, or 2.2%, in fiscal 2004 to $8.9 million from $8.7 million in fiscal 2003. The slight increase in pre-opening
expenses was primarily the result of opening 32 new Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores during fiscal 2004, compared with 31 new Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores during fiscal 2003. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Operating Profit </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s consolidated operating profit increased $18.4 million, or 8.2%,
to $244.2 million in fiscal 2004 from $225.8 million in fiscal 2003. Operating profit increased $45.6 million, or 19.6%, in fiscal 2004 excluding the operating losses of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com for the full period in fiscal 2004 compared with a
partial period in fiscal 2003. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Interest Expense, Net and Amortization of Deferred Financing Fees </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Interest expense, net of interest income, and amortization of deferred financing fees, decreased $9.9 million, or 47.4%, to $11.0 million in fiscal 2004
from $20.9 million in fiscal 2003. The decrease was primarily the result of the redemption of the Company&#146;s $300.0 million 5.25% convertible subordinated notes, which resulted in a reduction of the Company&#146;s average borrowings and interest
rate. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Debt Redemption Charge </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the
second quarter of fiscal 2004, the Company completed the redemption of its $300.0 million outstanding 5.25% convertible subordinated notes due 2009. Holders of the notes converted a total of $17.7 million principal amount of the notes into 545,821
shares of common stock of the Company, plus cash in lieu of fractional shares, at a price of $32.512 per share. The Company redeemed the balance of $282.3 million principal amount of the notes at an aggregate redemption price, together </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-9 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">with accrued interest and redemption premium, of $295.0 million. The write-off of the unamortized portion of the deferred
financing fees from the issuance of the notes and the redemption premium resulted in a charge of $14.6 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Equity in Net Loss of Barnes&nbsp;&amp;
Noble.com </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company accounted for its approximate 38% economic interest in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com under the equity method
through September&nbsp;15, 2003. Equity losses in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com were $14.3 million in fiscal 2003. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Income Taxes </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble&#146;s effective tax rate in fiscal 2004 increased to 43.00% compared with 41.35% during fiscal 2003. The increase in the
effective tax rate was primarily due to adjustments in fiscal 2004 related to prior year taxes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Minority Interest </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Minority interest was $1.2 million in fiscal 2004 compared with $0.5 million in fiscal 2003, and relates to the approximate 26% outside interest in
Calendar Club L.L.C. (Calendar Club). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Income From Discontinued Operations </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;1, 2004, the Board of Directors of the Company approved an overall plan for the complete disposition of all of its Class&nbsp;B common
stock in GameStop, the Company&#146;s former video game operating segment. This disposition was completed in two steps. The first step was the sale of 6,107,338 shares of GameStop Class&nbsp;B common stock held by the Company to GameStop (Stock
Sale) for an aggregate consideration of $111.5 million, consisting of $37.5 million in cash and a promissory note in the principal amount of $74.0 million, bearing interest at a rate of 5.5%&nbsp;per annum, payable when principal installments are
due. The Stock Sale was completed on October&nbsp;1, 2004. The second step in the disposition was the spin-off by the Company of its remaining 29,901,662 shares of GameStop&#146;s Class B common stock (Spin-Off). The Spin-Off was completed on
November&nbsp;12, 2004 with the distribution of 0.424876232 of a share of GameStop Class&nbsp;B common stock as a tax-free distribution on each outstanding share of the Company&#146;s common stock to the Company&#146;s stockholders of record as of
the close of business on November&nbsp;2, 2004. As a result of the Stock Sale and the Spin-Off, GameStop is no longer a subsidiary of the Company and, accordingly, the Company will present all historical results of operations of GameStop as
discontinued operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-10 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Earnings </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">As a result of the factors discussed above, the Company reported consolidated net earnings of $143.4 million (or $1.93 per share) during fiscal 2004 compared with net earnings of $151.8 million (or $2.07 per share) during fiscal 2003.
Components of diluted earnings per share (EPS) are as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE><HR WIDTH="8%" SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" ALIGN="left">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Includes a one-time charge of $0.11 per share associated with the redemption of the convertible notes in fiscal 2004. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Seasonality </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s business, like that
of many retailers, is seasonal, with the major portion of sales and operating profit realized during the fourth quarter which includes the holiday selling season. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Working capital requirements are generally at their highest in the Company&#146;s fiscal
quarter ending on or about January&nbsp;31 due to the higher payments to vendors for holiday season merchandise purchases. In addition, the Company&#146;s sales and merchandise inventory levels will fluctuate from quarter to quarter as a result of
the number and timing of new store openings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cash and cash equivalents on hand, cash flows from operating activities, funds available
under its senior credit facility and short-term vendor financing continue to provide the Company with liquidity and capital resources for store expansion, seasonal working capital requirements and capital investments. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash Flow </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cash flows provided from operating
activities were $499.7 million, $532.4 million and $471.3 million during fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. In fiscal 2005, the decrease in cash flows from operating results was primarily due to the timing of rent payments. In fiscal 2004 and
2003, the increase in cash flows from operating activities was primarily attributable to improved working capital management and an increase in net earnings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The weighted-average age per square foot of the Company&#146;s 681 Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores was 7.7 years as of January&nbsp;28, 2006 and is expected to increase to approximately 8.2 years by February&nbsp;3,
2007. As the Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores continue to mature, and as the number of new stores opened during the fiscal year decreases as a percentage of the existing store base, the increasing operating profits of Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores
are expected to generate a greater portion of the cash flows required for working capital, including new store inventories, capital expenditures and other initiatives. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Capital Structure </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Strong cash flows from operations and a continued emphasis on working capital
management strengthened the Company&#146;s balance sheet in fiscal 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-11 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;17, 2005, the Company, together with certain of its subsidiaries, entered into a Credit
Agreement (the New Facility) with a syndicate led by Bank of America, N.A. and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. The New Facility replaces the Amended and Restated Credit and Term Loan Agreement, dated as of August&nbsp;10, 2004 (the Prior Facility), which
consisted of a revolving credit facility and a term loan. The revolving credit facility portion was due to expire in May 2006 and the term loan had a maturity date of August&nbsp;10, 2009. The Prior Facility was terminated on June&nbsp;17, 2005, at
which time the prior outstanding term loan of $245.0 million was repaid. Letters of credit issued under the Prior Facility, which totaled approximately $30.0 million as of June&nbsp;17, 2005, were transferred to become letters of credit under the
New Facility. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The New Facility provides for a maximum aggregate borrowing amount of $850.0 million (which under certain circumstances may
be increased to $1.0 billion at the option of the Company) and terminates on June&nbsp;16, 2010. The maximum aggregate borrowing amount may be reduced from time to time according to the terms of the New Facility. Borrowings made pursuant to the New
Facility may be committed loans or swing line loans, the combined sum (including any outstanding letters of credit) of which may not exceed the maximum borrowing amount. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Borrowings made pursuant to the New Facility as committed loans will bear interest, payable quarterly or, if earlier, at the end of any interest period, at either (a)&nbsp;the base rate, described in the New Facility
as the higher of Bank of America N.A.&#146;s prime rate (7.25% as of January&nbsp;28, 2006) or the federal funds rate (4.38% as of January&nbsp;28, 2006) plus 0.50%, or (b)&nbsp;the Eurodollar rate (a publicly published rate which was 4.57% as of
January&nbsp;28, 2006) plus a percentage spread (ranging from 0.750% to 1.375%) based on the Company&#146;s consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio. Swing line loans bear interest at the base rate. Under the New Facility, the Company agrees to pay
a commitment facility fee, payable quarterly, at rates that range from 0.150% to 0.300% depending on the Company&#146;s consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio. The payments under the New Facility are guaranteed by material subsidiaries of the
Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The New Facility contains customary affirmative and negative covenants for credit facilities of this type, including limitations
on the Company and its subsidiaries with respect to indebtedness, liens, investments, distributions, mergers and acquisitions, disposition of assets, sale-leaseback transactions, and transactions with affiliates. The New Facility permits the Company
to use proceeds of the credit loans and letters of credit for working capital and capital expenditures and for all other lawful corporate purposes, including payment of dividends, acquisitions of assets, capital stock of other companies and share
repurchases, in each case to the extent permitted in the New Facility. The New Facility also contains financial covenants that require the Company to maintain a minimum consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.75 and a maximum consolidated
funded debt to earnings ratio of 2.00. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The New Facility provides for customary events of default with corresponding grace periods,
including failure to pay any principal or interest when due, failure to comply with covenants, any material representation or warranty made by the Company proving to be false in any material respect, certain bankruptcy, insolvency or receivership
events affecting the Company or its subsidiaries, defaults relating to certain other indebtedness, imposition of certain judgments and a change in control of the Company (as defined in the New Facility). </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;28, 2004, the Company completed the redemption of its $300.0 million outstanding 5.25% convertible subordinated notes due 2009. Holders of
the notes converted a total of $17.7 million principal amount of the notes into 545,821 shares of common stock of the Company, plus cash in lieu of fractional shares, at a price of $32.512 per share. The Company redeemed the balance of $282.3
million </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-12 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">principal amount of the notes at an aggregate redemption price, together with accrued interest and redemption premium, of
$295.0 million. The write-off of the unamortized portion of the deferred financing fees from the issuance of the notes and the redemption premium resulted in a charge of $14.6 million. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selected information related to the Company&#146;s term loan, convertible subordinated notes and the New and Prior Facilities: </FONT></P> <P

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Fees expensed with respect to the unused portion of the New and Prior Facilities were $1.3
million, $1.0 million and $1.2 million, during fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The amounts outstanding under the New and Prior
Facilities, if any, have been classified as long-term debt based on the Company&#146;s ability to continually maintain principal amounts outstanding. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has no agreements to maintain compensating balances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Capital Investment </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Capital expenditures totaled $187.2 million, $184.9 million and $130.1 million during fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. Capital expenditures in
fiscal 2006, primarily for the opening of 30 to 40 new Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble stores, the maintenance of existing stores and system enhancements for the retail stores and the Web site, are projected to be in the range of $190.0 million to $200.0
million, although commitment to many of such expenditures has not yet been made. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on current operating levels and the store expansion
planned for the next fiscal year, management believes cash and cash equivalents on hand, cash flows generated from operating activities, short-term vendor financing and borrowing capacity under the New Credit Facility will be sufficient to meet the
Company&#146;s working capital and debt service requirements, and support the development of its short- and long-term strategies for at least the next 12 months. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fiscal 1999, the Board of Directors of the Company authorized a common stock repurchase program for the purchase of up to $250.0 million of the Company&#146;s common stock. The Company completed this $250.0 million
repurchase program during the first quarter of fiscal 2005. On March&nbsp;24, 2005, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors authorized an additional share repurchase program of up to $200.0 million of the Company&#146;s common stock. The Company
completed this $200.0 million repurchase program during the third quarter of fiscal 2005. On September&nbsp;15, 2005, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors authorized a new share repurchase program of up to $200.0 million of the Company&#146;s
common stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-13 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Share repurchases under this program may be made through open market and privately negotiated
transactions from time to time and in such amounts as management deems appropriate. As of January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company repurchased 7,682,700 shares at a cost of approximately $282.7 million under these programs in fiscal 2005, bringing the
combined total of repurchases under these programs to 16,690,400 shares at a cost of approximately $479.0 million under these programs. The maximum dollar value of common shares that may yet be purchased under the current program is approximately
$171.0 million as of January&nbsp;28, 2006. During the first quarter of fiscal 2006 (through March&nbsp;31, 2006), the Company repurchased 1,602,000 shares at a cost of $68.2 million. All repurchased shares are held in treasury. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company completed its acquisition of all of Bertelsmann AG&#146;s (Bertelsmann) interest in barnesandnoble.com inc.
(bn.com) and barnesandnoble.com llc (Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com). The purchase price paid by the Company was $165.4 million (including acquisition related costs) in a combination of cash and a note, equivalent to $2.80 per share in bn.com or
membership unit in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com. The note issued to Bertelsmann in the amount of $82.0 million was paid in fiscal 2003. As a result of the acquisition, the Company increased its economic interest in Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com to
approximately 75%. On May&nbsp;27, 2004, the Company completed a merger (the Merger) of bn.com with a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company. The purchase price paid by the Company was $158.8 million (including acquisition related costs). Under the
terms of the Merger, the holders of bn.com&#146;s outstanding common stock, other than the Company and its subsidiaries, received $3.05 in cash for each share that they owned. The Merger was approved by the shareholders of bn.com at a special
meeting held on May&nbsp;27, 2004. As a result of the Merger, bn.com became a privately held company, wholly owned by the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-14 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company had no off-balance sheet arrangements as defined in Item&nbsp;303 of the Regulation S-K. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Impact of Inflation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company does not believe
that inflation has had a material effect on its net sales or results of operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Certain Relationships and Related Transactions </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See Note 17 to the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-15 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Critical Accounting Policies </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations discusses the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements require management to make estimates and assumptions in certain circumstances that affect amounts reported in the accompanying consolidated financial
statements and related footnotes. In preparing these financial statements, management has made its best estimates and judgments of certain amounts included in the financial statements, giving due consideration to materiality. The Company does not
believe there is a great likelihood that materially different amounts would be reported related to the accounting policies described below. However, application of these accounting policies involves the exercise of judgment and use of assumptions as
to future uncertainties and, as a result, actual results could differ from these estimates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Merchandise Inventories </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Merchandise inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market. Cost is determined primarily by the retail inventory method on the first-in, first-out
(FIFO) basis for 95% and 96% of the Company&#146;s merchandise inventories as of January&nbsp;28, 2006 and January&nbsp;29, 2005, respectively. The remaining merchandise inventories are recorded based on the average cost method. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Market is determined based on the estimated net realizable value, which is generally the selling price. Reserves for non-returnable inventory are based
on the Company&#146;s history of liquidating non-returnable inventory. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company also estimates and accrues shortage for the period
between the last physical count of inventory and the balance sheet date. Shortage rates are estimated and accrued based on historical rates and can be affected by changes in merchandise mix and changes in actual shortage trends. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Other Long-Lived Assets </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s other
long-lived assets include property and equipment and amortizable intangibles. At January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company had $806.4 million of property and equipment, net of accumulated depreciation, and $15.7 million of amortizable intangible assets,
net of amortization, accounting for approximately 26.0% of the Company&#146;s total assets. The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be
recoverable in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No.&nbsp;144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148;. The Company evaluates long-lived assets for impairment at the individual
store level, which is the lowest level at which individual cash flows can be identified. When evaluating long-lived assets for potential impairment, the Company will first compare the carrying amount of the assets to the individual store&#146;s
estimated future undiscounted cash flows. If the estimated future cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the assets, an impairment loss calculation is prepared. The impairment loss calculation compares the carrying amount of the assets to
the individual store&#146;s fair value based on its estimated discounted future cash flows. If required, an impairment loss is recorded for that portion of the asset&#146;s carrying value in excess of fair value. Impairment losses totaled $12.7
million, $0.0 million and $0.0 million in fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-16 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Goodwill and Unamortizable Intangible Assets </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At January&nbsp;28, 2006, the Company had $263.7 million of goodwill and $78.1 million of unamortizable intangible assets (i.e. those with an indefinite
useful life), accounting for approximately 10.8% of the Company&#146;s total assets. SFAS No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148;, requires that goodwill and other unamortizable intangible assets no longer be amortized, but
instead be tested for impairment at least annually or earlier if there are impairment indicators. The Company performs a two-step process for impairment testing of goodwill as required by SFAS No.&nbsp;142. The first step of this test, used to
identify potential impairment, compares the estimated fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount. The second step (if necessary) measures the amount of the impairment. The Company completed its annual impairment test on the goodwill in
November 2005 and deemed that no impairment charge was necessary. The Company has noted no subsequent indicators of impairment. The Company tests unamortizable intangible assets by comparing the estimated fair value to the carrying value of such
assets. Changes in market conditions, among other factors, could have a material impact on these estimates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Newly Issued Accounting Pronouncements
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">There were no accounting standards issued during the fiscal year ended January&nbsp;28, 2006 that are reasonably likely to affect the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Disclosure Regarding Forward-Looking Statements </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This report may contain certain forward-looking statements (within the meaning of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section&nbsp;21E of
the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) and information relating to the Company that are based on the beliefs of the management of the Company as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to the management of the Company. When
used in this report, the words &#147;anticipate,&#148; &#147;believe,&#148; &#147;estimate,&#148; &#147;expect,&#148; &#147;intend,&#148; &#147;plan&#148; and similar expressions, as they relate to the Company or the management of the Company,
identify forward-looking statements. Such statements reflect the current views of the Company with respect to future events, the outcome of which is subject to certain risks, including among others general economic and market conditions, decreased
consumer demand for the Company&#146;s products, possible disruptions in the Company&#146;s computer or telephone systems, possible work stoppages or increases in labor costs, possible increases in shipping rates or interruptions in shipping
service, effects of competition, possible disruptions or delays in the opening of new stores or the inability to obtain suitable sites for new stores, higher-than-anticipated store closing or relocation costs, higher interest rates, the performance
of the Company&#146;s online initiatives such as Barnes&nbsp;&amp; Noble.com, the performance and successful integration of acquired businesses, the successful and timely completion and integration of the Company&#146;s new distribution center, the
success of the Company&#146;s strategic investments, unanticipated increases in merchandise or occupancy costs, unanticipated adverse litigation results or effects, and other factors which may be outside of the Company&#146;s control. Should one or
more of these risks or uncertainties materialize, or should underlying assumptions prove incorrect, actual results or outcomes may vary materially from those described as anticipated, believed, estimated, expected, intended or planned. Subsequent
written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the Company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements in this paragraph. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">F-17 </FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">172,957</FONT></TD>
